text:
SUSAN CHORLEY: So I
was pastoring a church

in the North Shore
in Massachusetts,

and our son was
about two years old.

And we were not planning to
have another child at the time.

And then I discovered
that I was pregnant.

JESSICA ROBINSON:
I was in college.

I was dating someone, and I was
leaving to go to grad school,

and as I was leaving, I found
out that I was pregnant.

DEBBIE BAMBERGER: I was
one day late for my period,

so I did a pregnancy
test at work.

And the LINE showed
up as positive,

and I was just
really devastated.

SUSAN CHORLEY: I very much
wanted to have that child.
The timing wasn't right.

JESSICA ROBINSON: And I ended up
making the decision to go ahead
and have the abortion.

SUSAN CHORLEY: I didn't
feel that I could tell
anyone about what was going on.

I prayed a lot, tried to ask God
to be with me, to let me know

I was going to be OK,
take care of this life

that I couldn't
bring into my life.

I definitely feel a lot of
fear about being thrown out

of the church, or being told
I can't receive acceptance
or forgiveness on my own terms.

JESSICA ROBINSON: You
know, it was the hardest
thing I had ever gone through.
And I completely lost all faith.

And it was probably a good
five years before I really

felt like I'd found a faith--
in which is when I ended
up taking refuge in Buddhism.

DEBBIE BAMBERGER:
I think, having

a conversation about abortion
is important because I want

the people who are sitting in
these chairs, in the sanctuary,

to be aware that the woman
sitting next to them-- they

have had an abortion,
and there's nothing
to judge them about for that.

There's nothing in the Torah
that says abortion is wrong.

JESSICA ROBINSON: I
have made peace with it.

I want for people to be
able to learn and to know
that you can move forward.

And you can turn your
pain into a message.

And that it can really help
and support other people.

SUSAN CHORLEY: I want the faith
communities to be places where

people can go, and be themselves
completely, and be loved,
and accepted--

and trust that those people,
that are there with them,

will always be with
them, no matter what.
